brief_summary.textblock:
Maternal hypotension is a common side effect after spinal anesthesia for cesarean
      delivery.Decreased vascular resistance and cardiac output, due to sympathetic blockade1and
      blood pooling in blocked areas of the body respectively, are main causes of spinal
      anaesthesia-induced hypotension during Caesarean delivery.

      Cardiac output, which has shown to be a better predictor of organ and placental perfusion
      than arterial blood pressure.Few studies have measured CO after spinal anesthesia in the
      maternal population.This is largely because of the lack of availability of accurate and
      reproducible noninvasive measurement techniques. Up to now, preventing hypotension has
      continued to focus on arterial blood pressure variables, fluid, and ephedrine requirements
      as markers of cardiovascular status, because these are more easily measured.

      Investgators hypothesized that CO and PetCO2, in parturients with the degree of hypotension
      during spinal anaesthesia, would also have a positive and significant association.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Feasibility of PetCO2 Prediction Hypotension Under Spinal Anesthesia for Cesarean Section

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  full-term gestation (>36 and <41 weeks of gestation) with a singleton pregnancy

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  emergency cases

          -  placenta praevia

          -  preeclampsia

          -  cardiovascular or cerebrovascular disease

          -  morbid obesity with a BMI≥40

          -  contraindications to spinal anaesthesia

study_pop.textblock:
American Society of Anesthesiologists physical status I and II patients undergoing
        elective cesarean delivery under combined spinal-epidural (CSE) anesthesia

clinical_study.official_title: The Feasibility of PetCO2 Prediction Hypotension Under Spinal Anesthesia for Cesarean Section

authority: United States: Food and Drug Administration

primary_outcome.measure: value of PetCO2 and changes in artery pressure

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case-Only, Time Perspective: Prospective
